title: Tesco promises brand price match amid deal to buy back stores
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Oct 12, 2015, 02:15 BST - UK Markets open in 5 hrs 45 mins Tesco promises brand price match amid deal to buy back stores By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 1 hour 13 minutes ago 0.00 0.00 
Britain's biggest supermarket is prmising to match prices on thousands of brands, as it seeks to take back control of a clutch of stores 
Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) has launched a fresh salvo in the supermarket price wars, pledging to offer an immediate price match on thousands of brands at its tills. 
The move, which the struggling supermarket giant claims is a first, is the most drastic of price-cutting measures taken by the big chains as they mount a fight back against Aldi and Lidl. 
The new “Brand Guarantee” scheme, which will be unveiled on Monday, promises to automatically deduct the difference a customer’s shop is more expensive that it would have been at Asda, Morrisons or Sainsbury’s. 
Tesco has been forced to take drastic action after it was hit by an accounting scandal and posted the biggest loss inits history. 
The Telegraph has learnt that under the leadership of new chief executive Dave Lewis , the grocer is in negotiations to buy back a clutch of supermarkets sold four years ago, as it begins to reverse the aggressive sale and leaseback programme pursued by former boss Philip Clarke (Toronto: CKI.TO - news ) . 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is understood that plans to buy three sites back in Shropshire, Lincolnshire and Birmingham sold to Legal and General for £46.5m in 2011. These are expected to be the first many prospective deals. 
Under Mr Clarke’s tenure Britain’s biggest supermarket sold 68 stores for £2.7bn in sale and leaseback transactions to help fund its global growth ambitions. At the time the agreements meant that Tesco could reduce its debt and realise value from its property portfolio. 
However, the 25 year lease obligations that sit on Tesco’s balance sheet have been a cause of concern in the City. Against an intensely competitive trading environment some shops had become unprofitable, eroding the margin gains of leasing the properties. 
This is partly because rent rises are pegged to the retail price index of inflation, rather than consumer price index, which means that Tesco’s rent bill is likely to rise faster than the price of a basket of goods in the current deflationary environment. 
As part of its strategy to increase the proportion of its freehold supermarkets Tesco sealed a £733m property swap in March with British Land (LSE: BLND.L - news ) to take back 21 superstores which reduced the company’s lease commitments and insulated it from indexed rent reviews. 
The deal took Tesco’s freehold ownership up to 55pc. Tesco is now looking to use the proceeds of the £4.2bn sale of its South Korean Homeplus business to protect and strengthen its balance sheet. At the time of the deal to Asia’s private equity firm MBK Partners Tesco said that it would “consider value accretive opportunities across the group including the selective purchase of some existing leasehold stores in the UK.” 
“It’s good that they are gaining control by owning the stores as it reduces their rent liabilities. But in writing a big check they have to be sure that they can make substantial operating improvements to justify the increase in debt”, said Clive Black, analyst at Shore Capital. 
Tesco last week called an end to its asset sale programme and said that it would not need a rights issue to improve the balance sheet. Instead Mr Lewis claimed that a “self-help” programme would shore up the business, despite posting a halving in operating profits. 
Tesco declined to comment on the potential deal to buyback its stores (Other OTC: UBGXF - news ) .
